data.text:
A family, a church, a community mourns…

Julie D’Agostino loses fight with CF

By Dee Longfellow

For The Elmhurst Independent

She was a gift to all who had the fortune of knowing her and left a lasting impression on everyone she met. She lit up the world with her smile and lit up the stage with her singing, dancing and acting.

Julie Carr D’Agostino, 22, of Elmhurst, passed away on Friday, August 7, 2015, surrounded by her loving family and friends. She was the beloved daughter of Mario and Mary Carr D’Agostino; loving sister to Michael, Kevin, Elizabeth (fiancé Ryan Hogan), Carly, and twin sister Natalie; adored niece, cousin, and friend to many; loyal companion to her dogs Tino and Kiwi.

Deemed “Warrior Princess,” Julie fought a brave and courageous battle to the end, always maintaining a positive attitude and never wanting to give up despite the overwhelming obstacles in her way, family members said. In her short life, Julie achieved a “Ph.D.” (Personally her Degree) in design, fashion, cooking, organizing, crafting and hosting. She will always be remembered for her strength, resilience, loyalty, love of Meryl Streep, fondness of shopping and all things pink. Heaven is likely a little pinker with her in it. Since Julie’s passing, there have been pink ribbons gracing numerous trees in south Elmhurst around the area of Visitation Church.

About four years ago, the Independent brought you a story about Julie, her struggle to maintain her health and her double-lung transplant in October of 2011.

Born a twin on November 10, 1992, alongside her sister Natalie, Julie faced struggles healthy children never have to.

“Natalie did everything. I’d get upset sometimes when I couldn’t do things,” said Julie. “I did have a few outbursts when I was younger, but nothing too much. And [as the sickness progressed], I was so oblivious and so sick, I don’t even remember anything.”

“You’ve gotta understand,” said Julie’s father Mario. “She’s got a fantastic attitude.”

Prior to her lung transplant, hundreds of faithful Visitation parishioners prayed many times as Julie’s body continued failing as she waited for lungs that would help her breathe on her own again.

Prayers were answered on October 24, 2011, when Julie underwent a successful surgery that placed two healthy lungs inside her chest. Months prior to the surgery, Julie’s health had been rapidly declining due to complications from Cystic Fibrosis.

“We have 16 steps in our house. Julie would come down the stairs once in the morning and not go back up until bedtime,” said Mary D’Agostino, Julie’s mother. “She could not go back up the stairs, she was not strong enough. We’d run up the stairs for her.”

After the operation she could go up and down the stairs on her own with ease. Julie said her new lungs brought her so much more than just good breaths and the ability to eat her favorite foods or be more active.

It was such a story, her friend and neighbor Giancarlo Iannotta called it a miracle and he later directed and produced the movie, “Miracle on South Street: The Julie D Story.” There was hardly a dry eye in the house, when nearly 200 people of the Visitation community attended a viewing in the Valentino Center.

“The whole experience brought so many people closer,” said Iannotta. “Her story touched so many people.”

“Every year for my birthday I wished for a cure to CF,” Julie said. “When I was in the ICU, I didn’t care about the latest iPad or iPod. I know love is all you need – and your family. If you’re stripped of everything else, but have that – that’s all you need.”

Too numerous to list, her family wishes to thank all of those who helped Julie on her journey, prayed for her strength and worked tirelessly to comfort her.

Friends and family met for a Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, August 12, 2015, at Visitation Catholic Church in Elmhurst. Interment Queen of Heaven Catholic Cemetery, Hillside.

In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Gift of Hope Organ & Tissue Donor Network, Attn: Gwendolyn Blakemore, 425 Spring Lake Drive, Itasca, 60143; or, Make a Wish America, 4742 N. 24th Street, Suite 400, Phoenix, AZ 85016-4862; or, Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 6931 Arlington Road, 2nd floor, Bethesda, MD 20814. Arrangements handled by Gibbons Funeral Home, Elmhurst. For more information, call 630-832-0018 or visit gibbonsfuneralhome.com

Richard W. Braunshausen Sr., formerly of Villa Park, passed away recently at the age of 89. He was a veteran of the U.S. Air Force and served during WWII. Beloved husband of the late Alice J. Loving father of Richard W. Jr. (Valerie), Patricia (George) Mangriotis, John (Lucie), Robert (Paula), Christine Burger, Bonnie Lullo and Kenneth (Ric Mundell). Dear grandfather of 22; great-grandfather of 14. Fond brother of Walter (Eileen) and Charles (Denise). Uncle and great uncle of many.

Richard (known in his younger years as “Dick”) lived a full life. He grew up in Maywood, one of three boys born to German immigrant parents. He joined the US Air Force shortly before his 18th birthday and completed training as a bombardier just as the war was ending. After traveling for his job, in 1950, he married the love of his life Alice Jean Mueller. They had seven children, eventually settling in Villa Park to raise them.

Working mostly in the automotive parts business, Richard owned a parts store for several years. He was very much a family man, spending all his spare time with his wife and children boating on Lake Geneva, creating wonderful memories, and vacationing in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. His love of wooden boats was only surpassed by his love for his family. He suffered a devastating blow when his wife of 25 years passed in 1975. He continued on, doing his best to raise his remaining at-home children on his own. He was a caring and accepting man, involving his children in everything he did. He loved having a large family, seeing the grandkids, and being surrounded by them. It was comforting to him and you would often find him asleep amidst the chaos.

Affectionately known by some as “Mr. B.,” he was well respected and loved by many. He passed peacefully, surrounded by his children, and will finally be reunited with his bride.

Funeral service was held on Wednesday July 29, 2015, at the Steuerle Funeral Home, 350 S. Ardmore Ave., Villa Park. Interment Queen of Heaven Cemetery, Hillside. In lieu of flowers memorials to Judd Goldman Adaptive Sailing Foundation visit juddgoldmansailing.org Arrangements provided by Steuerle Funeral Home. Call (630) 832-4161 or visit steuerlefh.com for more information.

Elmhurst – According to a release issued by Elmhurst School District 205, Elmhurst resident Milton (Milt) Francis Honel passed away June 8, 2015, after a long illness. He was 86.

“It is with sadness that District 205 announces the news that Milt Honel, former Principal and past School Board member of District 205, has passed away,” the release read. It added that there would be a memorial service held at Mary Queen of Heaven Catholic Church in Elmhurst on Saturday, July 18 with Visitation from 9 a.m. until time of mass at 10 a.m.

Born in Chicago, Honel proudly served in the army for a year after which, he received his masters and doctorate degrees in education from Loyola University and Northern Illinois University.

He married Rosalie Walsh on June 20, 1953; they enjoyed nearly 62 years of marriage. Milt and Rosalie had an exceptionally close and supportive marriage; Milt demonstrated his love for Rosalie by helping to care for her until recently as her health deteriorated due to Alzheimer's disease.

Milt worked as a school principal at various elementary schools including Parkview, Nixon, Edison, Washington and Field located in Morton Grove, Westchester, and Elmhurst. A lifelong learner and educator, he also taught at National-Louis University, Elmhurst College and College of DuPage (COD).

Achieving the Eagle Scout rank as a young man was something that made Milt proud. He passionately enjoyed politics, religious activities, reading, cross-country skiing, winter and summer camping, canoeing, and backpacking. He had an enduring interest in the world around him.

Survivors include his wife Rosalie (Walsh) Honel; children Marian (Jim Wilson) Honel-Wilson, Pat (John) Fogarty, Michael, Martin (Marie), Terese (Richard) Bailey, Cindy (Tim) Webster, 15 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his mother Frances (nee Sulan) and father Frank Honel.

In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to United Parent Support for Downs Syndrome, 1070 S. Roselle Rd., Schaumburg, 60193 or call (847)895-2100.

Arrangements provided by Countryside Funeral Homes. For more information, call (630)529-5751 or visit countrysidefuneralhomes.com

James M. Pagni passed away peacefully on Sunday, May 3, 2015, at Lexington Nursing Home in Elmhurst at the age of 91. He was born on August 24, 1923. Beloved husband of Vilma "Vee," nee Carmignani, for a loving 66 years. Jim moved his family from Cicero to Elmhurst in 1963, where they moved into a home in the brand new Park Manor subdivision on the south side.

As a child, Jim attended Morton East High School in Cicero, where he was a three-year captain of the state champion soccer team, and excelled at baseball and basketball as well.

A U.S. veteran, Jim proudly served our country as an airplane mechanic during World War II. Jim could fix or build just about anything and was constantly working around the house, building everything from trellises to wood-trimmed bars. He worked for General Electric for 20 years and then as a handy-man, maintenance manager for Mayslake Peabody Mansion in Oak Brook.

When not working, Jim enjoyed volunteering as a youth baseball coach in Elmhurst.

Jim's parents moved to Cicero from Lucca, Italy, in 1913. Jim was one of nine siblings. His family met new neighbors across the street who ironically also moved from the same region of Italy. Jim's eventual wife, Vilma, was the neighbors' only child. A humble man, who didn't have or ask for much, Jim was able to build a happy life for his family in Elmhurst. His gift of time to anyone in need was where his wealth was sustained.

Jim was also the devoted father of Colette Pagni-Schuten, Jim (Patti) and the late Renee Pagni-Eady. Loving son of the late Azio and the late Columba, nee Della Marjorie, Pagni. Fond grandfather of Courtney Schuten, Michael (Megan) Eady, James, Jr., Julia and Joseph Pagni. Fond great-grandfather to Lorelai and Greyson Eady. Dear brother of the late Reno "Pug" (the late Florence; the late Ann), the late Yolanda (the late Geno) Grilli, the late Alexander "Buff" (the late Josephine), the late Pete (the late Florence), the late Hugo, the late Dolores (the late George) Strand, the late Mario and the late Theresa. Dear uncle and great uncle to many. A Mass of Christian Burial was held at Visitation Parish, Elmhurst. Entombment at Queen of Heaven Cemetery, Crucifixion Garden. Please visit James's personal tribute website at russohillsidechapels.com to sign his guestbook.

Vernon Philip Soukup died of natural causes on April 10, 2015, at the age of 89. Born December 15, 1925, to Erwin Rudolph and Libby Vlasta Soukup, he was predeceased by Joanne (nee Keepers), his wife of nearly 55 years. He is survived by his loving daughters Nancy (Rich) Peterson, Martha (Michael Walsh) Soukup, Carolyn (Martin Maney) Soukup and Claudia (Ken) Beach. He was also predeceased by his brother, the Reverend Erwin Myron Soukup and is survived by brother Alan John Soukup.

Vernon was born in Wheaton and attended Wheaton Community High School. Following graduation, he attended DePauw University under the Navy V-12 officer training program for three years where he was commissioned as an officer and following that, graduated from the University of Illinois where he also attended two years of law school. In the early 1950’s, Vernon became owner of Soukup’s Hardware in Wheaton following his father’s retirement. He owned and operated the store for more than thirty years.

Upon Vernon’s retirement, he and Joanne moved to Algonquin where he lived for 28 years. Vernon was a member of First Presbyterian Church in Wheaton while residing there and Presbyterian Church of Barrington upon the move to Algonquin. At both churches, he served as an usher, Deacon and Elder. Vernon remained active in the Wheaton Rotary Club until last year, and helped coordinate that club’s student foreign exchange program in the 1970s and 1980s. He had a perfect attendance record, attending meetings while out of town or out of the country even if he didn’t speak the language.

In Algonquin, Vernon volunteered for Good Shepherd Hospital and Meals with Wheels. Vernon and Joanne traveled the world and met many friends during their travels. They were patrons of the arts, collecting artwork from their foreign journeys, and enjoying live theatre and orchestra concerts frequently. Vernon truly lived the Rotary motto “Service Above Self” his entire life.

Memorial Services will be held on Saturday, June 13, 2015, at 10 a.m. at the Presbyterian Church of Barrington, 6 Brinker Rd, Barrington, with committal service in the Presbyterian Church of Barrington’s Memorial Garden and reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, Memorials would be appreciated to Rotary International, 1560 Sherman Ave., Evanston, 60210 (rotary.org); or the Elmhurst-Yorkfield Food Pantry, 1083 S. York Rd., Elmhurst. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Margaret L Novosad, a longtime Elmhurst resident, passed away Thursdaym March 26, 2015, at the Lexington Health in Elmhurst, at the age of 90. Beloved wife of the late Andrew; loving mother of Steven (Susan), Russell (Gail) and the late Deborah Bartuska; grandmother of Laura, Carolyn, Jack, Sarah, Andrew, Alyssa, Nicholas (Kaitlyn) and Kathryn; great grandmother of William, Abigail and Owen; dearest sister of Doris Haesemeyer; aunt of many nieces and nephews.

Born March 19, 1925, a small town girl, Margaret grew up in Stanwood, Iowa, at a time when girls basketball was very popular. In 1942, she and her sister Doris led the Stanwood High School six-player girls basketball team to the Iowa State Quarterfinals. That year she would be elected to the 4th Iowa All-State Girls basketball team. Later, she could be seen playing one-on-one with her sons in the family driveway along with giving advice on shooting.

She attended the University of Iowa where she met Andy, whom she married in 1947 in Iowa City, Iowa. After living in St. Louis and Chicago, they finally settled in Elmhurst in 1956 where she and Andy raised their three children, while becoming very involved in the community.

Margaret and Andy both served as president of the Sandburg Jr. High PTA. She was president of the Elmhurst Evening Women's Club, where she spearheaded the fundraising and acquisition of the first mobile bandstand that was used in Wilder Park.

Once her children grew older, Margaret went back to school and received her teaching degree from Elmhurst College. She went on to teach freshman and senior English at York High School from 1970-1990. One of her favorite books she had her students read was Watership Down, which accounted for her collection of rabbit items.

After retirement from York, and up until last year, she and her sister Doris would spend part of the winter in Casey Key, Florida, where family and friends would come to visit. This yearly adventure that was one of the highlights of her year.

Another of her greatest joys was her family. Margaret loved being around all her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Christmas was always a very special time for her, especially when Debbie and her family would make the trek from Virginia and all the family was together.

She had a great sense of humor and was a great "straight woman," setting up the punch lines for Andy and, later, her sons’ jokes. She was always a "cup half-full" person who looked on the positive side with a "this too shall pass" outlook when things weren't so rosy.

Memorial Visitation will be held on Saturday, April 25, 2015, beginning at 11 a.m. until time of Memorial Service at 11:30 at Messiah Lutheran Church, 130 W. Butterfield Rd., Elmhurst. Interment Mt. Emblem Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials would be appreciated for the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Former “First Lady” of Elmhurst College dies at 86

Ruth Hudson Frick spearheaded several endeavors at college, community

Elmhurst -- From 1971 until 1994, Ruth Hudson Frick was the First Lady of Elmhurst College, where she led and belonged to a number of organizations that enhanced the life of the community both at the College and beyond.

Mrs. Frick, of Lancaster, Penn., and formerly of Elmhurst, died peacefully on Wednesday, April 1, 2015, at the age of 86, at The Glen of Willow Valley Retirement Communities in Willow Street, Penn.

Born in Findlay, Ohio, Ruth Hudson Frick was the daughter of Ray M. Hudson and Ethel Leidigh Hudson. She graduated from Iowa City High School in Iowa in 1946, and from Findlay College in Findlay, Ohio, in 1950. Married on July 16, 1950, she was the loving wife of Ivan E. Frick for more than 64 years.

Mrs. Frick served as First Lady of Findlay College from 1964 to 1971, and became First Lady of Elmhurst College when her husband became its 11th president in 1971.

In receiving the Founders Medal from Elmhurst in 1992, Mrs. Frick was recognized for the “untold hours” she spent on behalf of the College that made her “a full partner in her husband’s presidency of accomplishments.” A member of both the Elmhurst College Association and the Elmhurst College Women’s Auxiliary, she founded Elmhurst: College and Community, an organization dedicated to building a dynamic relationship between the College and the city. When she and her husband retired, Elmhurst College honored them for their service by renaming the campus’s student union building the Frick Center.

Mrs. Frick was an elementary and high school teacher during the earliest phase of her career, and later in her life would hold a position with the Board of Illinois Literacy Inc., as well as become a tutor with the Laubach Literacy Program. She also was a longtime member of the American Association of University Women (AAUW), the Elmhurst Memorial Hospital Guild, the League of Women Voters, the Ray Graham Association and the Elmhurst Symphony Orchestra Auxiliary.

She was a member of the College First Church of God in Findlay, Ohio; St. Peter’s United Church of Christ in Elmhurst; First Congregational Church of Western Springs; and Hamilton Park United Church of Christ in Lancaster, Penn.

Besides her husband Ivan, Mrs. Frick is survived by her children, David (Ingrid Plajzer) of Kensington, Calif.; Daniel (Tamara Goeglein) of Lancaster, Penn.; Susan (Ronald Searl) of Westmont, Ill.; and, her five granddaughters, Rachel Foster, Sarah Roster, Eleanor Frick, Evelyn Frick and Lillie Frick. Also surviving are her brother James Melvin (Hazel Martin) of Cedar Rapids, Iowa; and a sister-in-law, Mary Hudson of Casey, Ill., along with many beloved nieces and nephews. Preceding her in death are her parents and one brother, Raymond Hudson.

Two memorial services are planned for Mrs. Frick. The first will be held on April 7 in Lancaster, Penn. The second service will be held on Saturday, May 2, at 11 a.m. in St. Peter’s United Church of Christ, 125 W. Church St., Elmhurst.

In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Frick Endowed Book Fund of Elmhurst College. To make your gift, visit elmhurst.edu/giving (After clicking on “Give Now,” select “Other” for type of donation and specify the Frick Endowed Book Fund), or call the Office of Development and Alumni Relations at (630) 617-6424. Gifts also may be mailed to: Elmhurst College, Attn: Office of Development, 190 So. Prospect, Elmhurst. Checks should be made payable to Elmhurst College and the memo line should reference the Frick Endowed Book Fund.

This information was provided by Elmhurst College.

Veronica Jane Rita Nelson Shallcross passed away recently. Beloved wife of the late David, the love of her life; mother of Barbara Schaff, David (Dorothy) Shallcross, Thomas (Anita) Shallcross and Veronica (James) Wing; grandmother of Len (Charlotte) Prescott, Lauren (Ryan) Dee, Nick (Amanda) Shallcross, Mark (Emily) Wing, Brittnay (Kyle) Hintz, and Molly (Dan) Amack; great grandmother of Karsyn, Oliver, and Emma Prescott, Holten, Ellen, and Paden Dee, Mason and Lane Hintz and Whitton, Declan, Emlyn, Audun, and Vivien Amack; sister of Jacqueline Hoffman; also survived by numerous nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends (especially “CLUB”)!!!!

Born December 20, 1926, at St. Mary of Nazareth Hospital in Chicago to Victor Hugo Nelson and Veronica Philomena Bly, Jane’s plan was to become a nun – until she met David Whitton Shallcross and her dreams changed. Jane and Dave were married on February 8, 1947, and had 51 wonderful years together. Always a loving and caring person, Jane was born to be a volunteer to work tirelessly for her church, school, and community. She was president of the Council of Catholic Women of Visitation Parish; president of the Joliet Diocesan Council of Catholic Women; a lay member of the U.S. Council of Catholic Bishops. She also served as a Representative of the City Council in Elmhurst. Jane was an active member of the League of Women Voters and Church Women United. Tireless! Jane was loved by everyone she met. She always said that if you have a life filled with JOY (Jesus first, Others second, Yourself third), you could not help but be happy.

Visitation will be held at Ahlgrim Funeral Home, 567 S. Spring Rd., Elmhurst, on Friday, April 17 from 6-8 p.m. Funeral services will be held Saturday, April 18 beginning with prayers at 9 a.m. at the funeral home, going on to Visitation Catholic Church for Mass at 9:30 a.m. Interment All Saints Cemetery. Memorials may be made in her name to Visitation Catholic Church, 779 S. York St, Elmhurst. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Carmela “Carmelina” Campione, nee Bruno, of Chicago, formerly of Nicosia, Sicily, Italy, passed away recently. Beloved wife of the late Domenico; loving mother of Santo (Kelly); grandmother of Dominic, Shannon and Nicholas; sister of the late Luigi, Peppina and Giuseppe; aunt of many nieces and nephews.

“The world lost a very special person on Saturday, April 4, 2015 – my Mom,” said Santo. “I say the world as I truly believe that my Mom made a difference in family and friends lives around the world, from Italy, to the U.S. and Australia. She will be missed by many. Our hearts are torn and weaken, but our spirits high as we know that my Mom is in a much better place. My Mom was the most beautiful woman I ever knew! All I am I owe to my Mom. I attribute all my success in life to the never-ending love, kindness and support I received from my Mom.

“One of my Mom’s favorite sayings was ‘Amor di madre, amore senza limiti.’ Translation – A mother’s love has no limits. This exemplified my Mom to the very end. I would like to add one more ‘Una madre e uno che puo prendere il posto di tutti gli altri, ma il cui posto nessun altro puo prendere.’ Translation – A mother is one who can take the place of all others, but whose place no one else can take. Mom, I LOVE YOU!”

Funeral services were held on Saturday, April 11, 2015 at Visitation Church. Entombment Resurrection Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, Memorials will be appreciated for the American Heart Association, Midwest Affiliate, Attn: Memorial/Tribute Processing Center, 208 S. LaSalle St., Suite 1500, Chicago, 60604. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Patricia (Tenebrini) McCarthy Daniel, nee Tenebrini, a 1960 graduate of Immaculate Conception High School, who resided in Elmhurst for much of her life, died peacefully and surrounded by family on March 5, 2015 at her home in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 72.

Pat was born on January 15, 1943, in Chicago, the daughter of Columbo “Jack” and Helen Tenebrini. Pat spent her childhood growing up in Chicago and then Elmhurst with her two older sisters Mary Lou and Gloria and her younger brother Paul.

After graduating from Immaculate Conception, Pat enrolled at Webster University near St. Louis before leaving school. She was married in June 1962 and had two daughters, Karyn and Bridgett. She resided in Elmhurst until 1978, when she moved to Chicago.

Pat had an encouraging word for everybody, a voracious appetite for books and movies, and accumulated wide-ranging knowledge that she generously shared with others. In particular, she developed a keen medical mind that made her a de facto aches-and-pains adviser to family and friends.

In addition, Pat was an enthusiastic champion of others—a trait that served her well in the 1970s and ‘80s as a representative for advertising photographers, artists and other creative talents. During that time, she met the love of her life and future husband, Bill Daniel, who went on to become an advertising agency owner.

They traveled extensively, and in style, to an assortment of international locales. Their vacations took them to spots like Mexico, Jamaica, the Virgin Islands, the Bahamas, the United Kingdom, Portugal and Italy. Without fail, they came back with stories of adventure (and hilarious misadventure) that underscored the fast friendships they easily formed on their journeys.

Deeply intuitive, one time in the mid-1970s, Pat met a muscle-bound bouncer at a Chicago nightclub. After “reading” his palms, she assured him that he was bound for great fame. Within a few years, he was known globally as Mr. T.

Pat lived in Chicago from 1978 to 1994, then moved with Bill to Oak Park to be close to her two daughters and their families. For the next 11 years, Pat and Bill’s home on North Taylor Avenue was a frequent hub of social activity, from her daughter Bridgett’s backyard wedding to holiday, birthday and a variety of other celebrations.

In that time, Pat also delighted in being part of the early years of her four grandchildren, Natalie & Zane Lindeman, and Zach & Maggie Rose Baron.

She and Bill moved to Palm Springs in 2005, where they lived near her brother and his wife. Most recently, she hosted Thanksgiving for more than 25 family and friends visiting from near and far. In semi-retirement, Pat also worked as a production listings coordinator for “Below the Line,” a movie industry newsletter that serves as “the voice of the crew.”

Her entertainment industry roots date back to the 1980s, when she began working primarily as a production coordinator on movies and television shows that filmed in Chicago. Her credits include “ER,” “Chicago Hope,” and “Fred Claus.” In that capacity, Pat was a beloved “mother hen” to the many men and women she worked alongside for more than 20 years.

Pat will be remembered in many ways but perhaps most by her hearty laugh, her ubiquitous reading glasses and her child-like zest for seeing the extraordinary beauty in what others would dismiss as the ordinary of life.

Pat was preceded in death by her parents; her sisters, Mary Lou Kubitz and Gloria Pekelsma; and her brother-in-law Al Kubitz.

Survivors include her husband Bill; her daughters Karyn (Les Lindeman) McCarthy and Bridgett (Matt) Baron; her adopted daughter Brittny; her brother Paul and his wife Nina Ushana; grandchildren Natalie, Zane, Zach and Maggie Rose; her former husband, Tim McCarthy; brother-in-law Glenn Pekelsma; nephews John (Darla Jo) Kubitz, Jim (Joy) Kubitz, Jeff (Robin) Pekelsma; nieces Susan Kubitz, Pam Ziarko, Chris (Tom) Hanchin and Jennifer (Steve) Kane; and many other relatives and friends.

At Pat’s request, there were no funeral services. Instead, and in keeping with her fun-loving spirit, she called for celebrations of her life. The first was held on April 4th in Palm Springs and another one is set for May 9th—the day before Mother’s Day—in Oak Park.

For more information, please visit celebratingpatty.com. Information was provided by the family.

Judi Lee Fox, 59, of Moline, passed away March 29, 2015, at her home, Heritage Fifty-Three, in Moline, Ill. Family and friends are invited to celebrate the life and spirit of this remarkable daughter, sister, niece, aunt, great-aunt and cousin at her home, Heritage Fifty-Three, 4601 53rd Street, Moline, on Sunday, April 26, 2015 from 1-4 p.m. Memorials in honor of Judi Lee Fox

may be made to Heritage Fifty-Three, 4601 53rd Street, Moline, IL 61265. Heritage Fifty-Three is a residential center of the ARC of the Quad Cities area.

Judi Lee was born December 3, 1955, in Moline, Illinois to William M. Fox and Dolores I. (Shrader) Fox. She moved from her parents’ home in Rock Island on December 10, 1979, becoming one of the first residents of Heritage Fifty-Three, a state-of-the-art community facility which was specifically designed to meet the needs of individuals with physical and developmental disabilities in their home communities.

She enjoyed a full life, including vacations at Saint Colleta and Loud Thunder summer camp programs. Judi frequently took long weekends and vacations at her beloved Cabin on Alpha Lake, as well as often visiting her sister, brother, nieces and nephew in Elmhurst. She

particularly enjoyed visiting her family: seeing the Christmas displays downtown, singing Christmas carols and camp songs, attending parades, celebrating birthdays, and swimming.

Judi enjoyed an active social life with her friends and family at Heritage Fifty-Three including, seeing “Elvis,” attending SPEC parties, dances, ice cream socials, trips on the riverboat, plays at local theatres and countless community events. Some of Judi’s favorite things included: pizza, ice cream, singing, looking at family picture catalogues, and creating mischief.

Judi was preceded in death by her beloved father, William M. Fox (“Bill Fox the Man.”) She is survived by her mother, Dolores Fox of Rock Island; her sister, Jeri Lynn Fox (husband Michael Kuhlman) of Elmhurst; brother William C. Fox of Elmhurst; nieces Christine and Nicole Kuhlman, and Emily Fox, all of Elmhurst; and nephew William S. Fox (wife Kylee) of Rock Island; a great nephew, William “Jude” Fox of Rock Island; and numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. Online condolences may be left to Judi's family at wheelanpressly.com. Arrangements provided by Wheelan-Pressly Funeral Home in Rock Island. For more information, call 309-786-5421 or visit wheelanpressly.com.

Visitation Thurs., Funeral Fri., Mar. 6

William “Bill” Everson, of Elmhurst, died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage on Wednesday, February 25, 2015, at the age of 71.

He was born on October 2, 1943 in Boca Raton, Florida, the son of Elmer “Mike” and Martha “Maddie” Everson. He spent the first few years of his life in Boca Raton while his engineer father, a Captain in the Army Air Corps, taught RADAR to American Airmen. After the war, the family moved to Evansville, Ind. At age 7, Bill lost his father and was raised by his hard-working mother. Following in his father’s footsteps, Bill earned his ham radio license at age 13, a hobby that he kept up throughout his life. He attended Redeemer Lutheran Grade School and Central High School in Evansville. He earned a degree in electrical engineering from Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Terre Haute, Ind., where he was a member of the basketball team and Sigma Nu Fraternity.

Directly after graduating from Rose-Hulman, Bill began a career at Commonwealth Edison in Chicago that would last 31 years. Bill married Judith Margaret Bradley on August 31, 1968, and soon after, earned an M.B.A. from Northwestern University’s Kellogg School of Management. The couple settled in Elmhurst, where they remained residents for 44 years. At Commonwealth Edison, Bill rose from engineer to executive management and continued his friendship with his “FOF” colleagues throughout his retirement.

Bill and Judy spent their retirement traveling, volunteering, and recently wintering in Sarasota, Florida. Bill was active in various volunteer activities and hobbies. He served as an Elder and board member of Redeemer Lutheran Church in Elmhurst. He was also on the board of Lutheran Child and Family Services and the Chicagoland Lutheran Education Foundation. As a member of the Fox Flying Club, he enjoyed flying single engine airplanes. Bill and Judy flew to numerous places, including Minnesota, Nova Scotia, New Orleans, Arizona, the Bahamas and around the island of Hawaii. Bill highly valued family vacations. His children fondly remember many trips across the country, often hearing Bill’s ham radio call sign from the passenger seat while he spoke to hams all over the world. During retirement he fulfilled his interest in genealogy, eventually going on vacation/research trips with Judy to Germany and Scandinavia, including the Valdres Valley, researching his Norwegian heritage.

Bill was predeceased by his parents. He is survived by wife Judy of 47 years, son Michael (fiancée Nancy Veltema) and daughter Elizabeth (Randall) Swartz, and numerous cousins and friends in Illinois and Florida.

Bill was a man who was interested in everything and always there to offer a helping hand. He was skilled at all sorts of craftsmanship, from working on the church organ and sound system to rehabbing his daughter’s two-flat. Bill was the go-to guy for so many: his family, his congregation, various organizations, his friends and neighbors. Bill was valued and respected for his talents, patience and ethics and he leaves behind shoes too big to fill. He is deeply mourned by family and friends.

Visitation at Ahlgrim Funeral Home, 567 S. Spring Rd., Elmhurst on Thursday, March 5 from 3-8 p.m.. Funeral Service at 10:00 a.m. Friday, March 6 at Redeemer Lutheran Church, 345 S. Kenilworth Ave, Elmhurst. Interment Queen of Heaven Cemetery, Hillside. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations are made in Bill's memory to Chicagoland Lutheran Education Foundation, 861 S. Church Road, Bensenville, IL 60106 or goodnewsfund.org. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

By Dee Longfellow

For The Elmhurst Independent

Many of the people who attended this year’s Elmhurst Hospital Foundation Chef Fest held on Thursday, February 19, came after attending the wake for Bill von Stein, former long-time Vice President of Development for Elmhurst Memorial Hospital, which placed him at the head of the Hospital Foundation. Ken Wegner, who knew Bill well because of all the fundraising they had done together, called for an extra round applause during the brief program portion at the 15th annual Chef Fest event.

“He wouldn’t have wanted a moment of silence,” Wegner said to the capacity crowd at Drury Lane. “So let’s give him another round of applause.”

Earlier in the evening, The Independent had a chance to speak personally with Wegner to hear his memories of the man who was often known as “Dollar Bill.”

“Bill had a huge heart, he always wanted to do good,” he said. “He worked very hard for the foundation, he was a wonderful person to work with and he really cared about people and about the hospital.”

Wegner frequently served as Chairman of the fall fundraising events that used to be held at The Carlisle, which were typically costume parties.

“Here’s the funniest stories I have about Bill,” he said. “One year Bill’s date came dressed as Marilyn Monroe and had bright red lipstick on. Well, I couldn’t find Bill for a while -- it was time to draw raffle tickets or something – and I couldn’t find him anywhere. When he finally showed up, he had the same lipstick on his own lips as well as all over his face!

“It was so funny moments because here’s Bill -- he’s so straight and narrow, all business, always doing the right thing. And now, his shirt was all rumpled and he had lipstick all over his face.”

Wegner said Chef Fest was a tribute to him, that he was very instrumental in the many events the hospital held over the years.

“He was a wonderful, wonderful man. The Foundation wouldn’t be what it is today without Bill von Stein.”

Darrell Whistler, who served many years on the Hospital’s Board of Governors, liked working with von Stein as well.

“What I really liked was how he would critique me,” he said. “Bill was on top of everything and every time we would do something, he would write down notes – he had beautiful printing – and he was very articulate. He would always go over his notes afterwards and tell me what we could have done better. That’s how he was, even if things were done well, he wanted to make them better.”

Betsy Hanisch had this to say: “He was a real friend to Elmhurst. He was one of the first people I met through my involvement with the [Elmhurst Chamber of Commerce] Board of Directors. At the time, they were trying to get business people more active with the hospital. Then 16 years ago, he helped me launch the Golf Outing that took place at River Forest. It was, he admitted, way beyond his comfort level – because he didn’t golf.”

Hanisch also talked about his retirement party.

“His retirement party was ‘Hats off to Bill’ – there was a coat tree with the many hats he wore – for Rotary, Boys and Girls Clubs, all the things he’d been involved in. It was a wonderful tribute.”

William B. von Stein was born on November 8, 1939, and passed away on February 17, 2015, at the age of 75. He was the beloved husband of the late Marilyn J., nee Donner. He is survived by two daughters Susan (Mike) McManus and Meg (Larry) Zelenovich; his stepchildren Patty Barnett, Mike Adamle, Mark (Susan) Adamle and Vic (Mary) Adamle. He was the proud grandfather of Kate, Carolyn and Mary and step-grandfather to many.

In addition to being Vice President of Development for Elmhurst Memorial Hospital, Bill von Stein was active with Elmhurst Rotary Club, was a volunteer at the Boys and Girls Club of West Cook County and was a member of Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity. In lieu of flowers, memorials will be appreciated for the Boys and Girls Club of West Cook County or to Elmhurst Memorial Hospital.

Funeral services were held on Friday, February 20, 2015, at Ahlgrim Funeral Home in Elmhurst. Interment Chapel Hill Gardens West Cemetery.

Bridget Ann Hancock, 68, of Trevor, passed away on Tuesday, January 13, 2015, at her daughter’s home surrounded by her loving family.

Born on October 9, 1946, in London, England, she was the daughter of the late John and Florence (Piper) O’Sullivan and one of nine children. She met her late husband John G. Hancock in London, while he was stationed at R.A.F Bentwaters, and they married on October 19, 1968. They had one daughter Stephanie before returning to the U.S.

She proudly accepted the role of a military wife and moved from England to air force bases in: Maine, Illinois, a second tour in England, North Dakota, Texas, and two bases in Illinois, including a last assignment at Great Lakes Naval Station. She became a member of the Officer Wives Club after John completed Officer Training School in 1979. During John’s last assignment at Great Lakes, they moved to Kenosha, Wisconsin, and John retired as a major from the military in 1993, and started a second career at the Kenosha County Courthouse until retirement in 2008. John passed away on December 8, 2008.

Over the years, Bridget worked part-time at some of the schools her daughter attended as an assistant and a “lunch lady.” She also worked retail sales at the Scott Air Force Base Exchange store and worked for many years in retail sales at the Company Store, Eddie Bauer and more recently Cole Haan in the Prime Outlet Mall. She thoroughly enjoyed working with her fellow employees and loved meeting and assisting the store customers over the years.

She & John owned many animals in their time together, including their beloved Brittanies, cats and horses. Bridget often accompanied John to dog show competitions, and the Brittany Club field trials and events, making friends with many fellow animal lovers. She also was a member of the British Wives Club and enjoyed gatherings with fellow women originally from the United Kingdom.

Those who knew and loved Bridget will remember her kindness, sense of humor, and her dedication to friends and family, including her daughter Stephanie (Ken) Nurczyk of Elmhurst, IL; her two beloved grandchildren Ryan & Sophia Nurczyk; her two sisters Josephine Roberts of England and Patricia Kerr of Brooklyn, NY, and sister-in-law Clarene (Gene) Perttula of North Adams, MI. She also leaves many other beloved family members and friends with her beautiful memory.

Funeral services will be held on Saturday, Jan. 24, 2015, at 3:30 p.m. at the Piasecki-Althaus Funeral Home. A visitation for Bridget will be hosted from 2 p.m. until the time of the service at the funeral home. A private interment will be held on at the Southern Wisconsin Veterans Memorial Cemetery in Union Grove. The family asks that you consider memorial remembrances to the American Cancer Society, American Brittany Rescue or St. Jude’s Children’s Research Hospital.

Edward J. Vertovec of Elmhurst, passed away on January 12, 2015, at the age of 91. He was born in Elmhurst on March 13, 1923, to Frank and Caroline Vertovec. He grew up in Elmhurst with his five siblings, Fran, Frank, Carl, Ray and Jean. He later graduated from Elmhurst College and received his law degree from DePaul University.

During World War II, he served in the Air Force, specializing in radar navigation training. Following his service, Ed married his beloved wife Betty J. Pace on June 21, 1947. According to Ed, Betty made their 67 years of marriage total happiness and bliss.

Ed lived and maintained a local law practice in Elmhurst where he championed numerous public works projects, including the advancement of the Chamber of Commerce and the Elmhurst Park District, along with Co-Chairing the Underpass Committee.

In 1988, Ed and Betty retired to Skidaway Island in Savannah, Georgia. Ed devoted countless hours to his lifelong love of volunteer work, donating his time to many organizations including the Chatham County Victim Witness Assistance Program, the Chatham County Juvenile Court Panels (which assisted judges in caring for minors), the Village Library at Skidaway, and the Howard Young Medical Center in Minocqua, Wisc. He was presented the Thousand Points of Light Volunteer Award by President George H.W. Bush in a ceremony in Salt Lake City.

When Ed and Betty moved back to Elmhurst in 2013, he began searching for the right volunteer job. After experiencing an incredible day in Washington, DC on the Honor Flight with his brother Ray and many other veterans, Ed became involved in aiding local veterans through his work at The Lexington including organizing a lecture from four Battle of the Bulge survivors just last week.

Ed will be remembered for his many great passions including travel, sports, reading and history. His life-long emphasis on fitness and working out began many years ago at the Elmhurst YMCA with his close friends, The Jolly Boys, and then continued at The Courts where he played tennis several times a week. He continued playing a bi-weekly game of tennis until he was 90.

Over the years he also played numerous sports including softball in an Elmhurst league, volleyball, and (perhaps most importantly) golf, which he continued well into his 80s. After retiring from most team sports, he happily sat in bleachers through rain, snow, sleet, sun and heat watching his descendants play a wide variety of sports. For the past 40 years, Ed and Betty also spent countless hours enjoying the comforts of their lake home in the north woods of Wisconsin with family and friends.

To know Ed was to love him. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather, great- grandfather and friend. His frequent greeting of, “Hello this is sweet and lovable Ed Vertovec,” always rang true. Ed was generous, kind, gentlemanly, positive, brilliant, and humble. He always had a smile on his face and a song on his tongue. He wrote amazing poetry for family occasions, his last being his beloved wife’s birthday, where he had the entire room in tears. Ed lived his long life with enthusiasm and optimism. He was always thinking of others and what he could do to help them. His sage advice was welcomed even this week. Ed will be missed more than words can express, but he has made the world a better place. His spirit and his goodness will live on in all whose lives he touched.

Ed is survived by Betty and their four children -- Kristine (Glenn) Rosenberger, Joe (Nancy Ebaugh), Mary, and Ann (David Audley). Ed was an enduring grandfather to nine grandchildren: Tiffani, Brian, Allison, Christopher, Hannah, Sam, Jordan, Ben, and Wil; and to three great grandchildren: Hope, Collin and Andrew. He is also survived by his brother, Ray (Anne) and his sister, Jean (Roman) Schmitt.

A Memorial Mass was held on Saturday, January 17 at Immaculate Conception Church, 134 Arthur, Elmhurst.

In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Honor Flight Inc., 300 E. Auburn Ave. Springfield, OH 45505 www.honorflight.org or The Village Library, 1 Skidaway Square, Savannah GA 31411, (912) 598-1183, thevillagelibrary.org.

[Ed. note: Just last week, the Elmhurst Independent began publishing columns that had appeared in SeLEXions, a literary journal written by residents of Lexington Square in Elmhurst. The first-ever column, appearing on the Viewpoint page of the January 15, 2015 edition of the Elmhurst Independent, was written by Ed Vertovec. The Elmhurst Independent mourns his loss and extends its sympathies to his family and loved ones.]

Jane Ellen (Bizzell) Re, 63, passed away on January 1, 2015, in the Venice, Florida hospital, after an illness. She was predeceased by her parents, Herman A. Bizzell and Dorothy (Pulhamus) Bizzell, for whom she cared tenderly in their last years.

Jane will be lovingly remembered by her son Ben Re, of Lexington, Kentucky; son Joe Re, of Villa Park, Illinois; sister Patricia Bizzell, of Worcester, Massachusetts, and her nieces Anna Herzberg, of Providence, Rhode Island, and Rachel Herzberg, of Tel Aviv, Israel; former husband Michael Re and wife Karen, of Carlsbad, California; his mother, Alice Re, and Don Smith, of Nokomis, Florida; Leslie (Re) and Paul Oslansky, of Cinncinatti, Ohio, and their daughter, Deanne, of Chicago, Illinois; and her long time family friend, Gladys Going, as well as many other friends.

Jane was born in Evanston, Illinois, on August 12, 1951, and lived most of her life in the Chicago area, eventually residing in the west suburb of Elmhurst where her family started and grew. As a young woman, she had a successful career as a photographic model, featured in a city-wide campaign for the Ford Motor Company. Later she obtained her realtor’s license and managed commercial property with the Inland Real Estate Group for many years. She retired to Nokomis in 2012.

Jane loved animals, and was never without a canine companion, including her Papillon, Mishka, who survives her. Jane was an accomplished horsewoman, and in earlier days enjoyed riding her quarterhorse mare, Clover. Equine and equestrian art adorns her home, much of it her own skillful drawing and painting. Jane’s love of animals and artistic ability combined in the recent launch of a business creating color portraits of dogs, from life or from photographs.

Above all, Jane valued her family and friends, and she would do anything for them. Her home was the center of Christmas celebrations for the whole family for many years. She was a gracious hostess with a great sense of humor. She will be sorely missed.

Cremation services in Florida will be private, and Jane’s ashes will be interred in the family plot in Kansas at a later time, when a memorial service will also be scheduled. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of one’s choice. To share a memory visit www.farleyfuneralhome.com

Richard George Wyrwa, 91, of Elmhurst, IL passed away peacefully at home on December 11, 2014, after a brief illness.

He was born in Lwow, Poland (now Lviv, Ukraine), on April 24, 1923. As a teenager, he supported his family through first the Russian and then German occupations of Eastern Poland during WWII, until he was taken at gunpoint and placed in a forced labor camp in Markranstadt, Germany for three years.

After the Americans liberated the camp in April of 1945, Mr, Wyrwa was recognized by the U.S. Army for his leadership skills and his ability to speak five languages and, at the age of 22, was appointed as Messing Officer for the entire refugee camp. He was later appointed Liaison to UNRRA (United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration and later to the IRO (International Relief Organization) to oversee several regional camps, where thousands of refugees from several nations benefited from his service in post-war West Germany.

Mr, Wyrwa married Wieslawa (Jane) Lippert on March 15, 1947, whom he had met while they were fellow forced laborers. In 1951, after several years of waiting, they finally obtained a permanent status visa and were able to immigrate to the U.S. with $50 in their pockets, which they used to buy gifts for their sponsors. He subsequently lived the American Dream, working hard during the day at any job he could get to support his family and then attending night school at Loyola University to earn a degree in business administration. Mr, Wyrwa later found employment at Perfect Plus Hosiery and worked his way up to being Senior Vice President. After the company was bought out by IC Industries, he was hired by Midas International Corporation and eventually became the Manager of Consolidations and Reporting, until he retired in 1987. Mr, Wyrwa was able to finally enjoy some well deserved rest in his retirement, playing his beloved Contract bridge, tending his plants and teaching his grandson how to play chess.

He is survived by his loving wife Wieslawa (Jane) and daughter Eva (Donald Miller) Wyrwa-Miller, grandson Robert Miller and nieces Grazyna (Paul) Lippert Zajaczkowska and Iwona Lippert.

He was preceded in death by his parents Adela (nee Lukowicz) and Edward Wyrwa; and by his only sibling, his brother Adam, who was killed at the age of 16 by the Nazis for being a Resistance fighter; and, by his dear son George, who drowned at the age of 16 trying to save another swimmer.

Funeral Mass was held on Monday, December 15, 2014, at Visitation Church in Elmhurst. Interment St. Adalbert Cemetery. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Greg Risberg, MSW, DSP and PFG (Pretty Funny Guy), of Elmhurst, died suddenly of natural causes on November 11, 2014, at the age of 67. Greg was a humorist and professional speaker whose hallmark was his uncanny resemblance to the farmer in Grant Wood's famous American Gothic painting. An article about Greg and his work features a photo of Greg, dressed in overalls and standing complete with pitchfork, next to the painting. He'd use the resemblance in his work by telling his audiences that they could find ways to have more humor in their lives, even if they came from a somber family, "like my parents."

During his 30-year career as a speaker, Greg spoke to more than half a million people, giving talks in 49 of the 50 states and in Canada, England, and Australia.

“I’m more saddened than words can express,” said his wife Madeleine. “I know that literally thousands of people have been touched by Greg’s talks. I have files full of your messages to him over the past 30 years, messages that told him how much his words moved you, or made you laugh, or helped you cope. Your responses to Greg were what made his work meaningful to him. “I had the privilege of being with Greg from the beginning of his speaking career, when we went to a local vendor to pick up stacks of newly-printed glossy brochures. At that time, I had no idea that I would be with him to the end of that journey.”

Greg was truly the warm, funny, people-person that you ever saw on stage, according to Madeleine. In Elmhurst, he knew people by name, who worked at the Jewel, the Ace Hardware, the Post Office, at Walgreen’s, etc.

He gave a talk for cancer survivors at an event sponsored by Elmhurst Hospital a few years ago. He also did at least one presentation for the staff of the Elmhurst Park District

Memorials are requested to the American Lung Association or to the Music Program at Unity Temple headed by Marty Swisher, 875 Lake Street, Oak Park, 60301. Greg loved the choir!

A third conviction Greg stood by was ending violence in any form. He was a conscientious objector during the Vietnam War, teaching at inner city schools as his alternative service. His heart was broken by the suffering that violence causes. For this reason, he stood at our services when the names of U. S. soldiers lost each week to war are read. He also stood for the civilian victims of war, for the soldiers lost on “the other side,” for the heart-breaking number of people in the city of Chicago lost in violence, whose names are also read at our service every week.

“I know he would be glad for any donations made to organizations dedicated to nonviolent means of bringing more peace and justice into our world,” Madeleine said.

There will be a Memorial Service for Greg at Unity Temple in Oak Park, on Saturday, December 20 at 2 p.m. Arrangements were provided by the family and at his web site at gregrisberg.com

Alvin Paul Klaeren, 86, of Newark, Ill., formerly of Elmhurst, passed away peacefully on Saturday, October 4, 2014, at his home surrounded by his loving family. He was born August 28, 1928 in Elmhurst, the son of John L. and Elfriede (Gerhardt) Klaeren. He married Carla E. Fladung on June 14, 1969, at the 1st United Methodist Church in Elmhurst. Alvin was a member of Salem Lutheran Church in Sandwich and First United Methodist Church of Elmhurst. He proudly served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War from 1950 to 1953.

Alvin was a licensed architect and a member of the American Institute of Architects. He played semi-pro football with the Elmhurst Travelers and was inducted into the American Football Association Hall of Fame in 2005. Alvin also was an avid water ski jumper and belonged to the 100 foot club. He was a beloved husband, father and grandfather and took great pride in his family.

He is survived by his wife, Carla of Newark, Ill.; one son, Chris (Kathy) Klaeren of Downers Grove, Ill.; three grandchildren, Jonny, Danny and Eleni; several nieces, nephews and cousins.

He was preceded in death by his parents; and by three brothers, Robert, Herbert and Raymond.

A Celebration of Life will be held on Saturday, October 25, 2014, at 11 a.m. at Salem Lutheran Church in Sandwich with the Reverend Wayne Derber officiating. Burial will be private. Visitation will be from 10 a.m. until the time of service on Saturday, October 25, 2014, at the church in Sandwich. Memorials may be directed to The Alzheimer’s Association, Salem Lutheran Church of Sandwich or First United Methodist Church of Elmhurst. Arrangements were entrusted to Turner-Eighner Funeral Home in Plano. For more information or to sign the online guest book, go to EighnerFuneralHomes.com.

Dorothy “Dot” Williams Wilson, of Elmhurst, died on October 1, 2014, at the age of 92. Mrs. Wilson was born to Homer and Betty Williams nee Robertson on January 23, 1922 in Keokuk, Iowa. Dorothy grew up in Carthage, Ill., and graduated from Knox College in Galesburg, Ill., in 1943.

After attending Officers Training for the Navy at Smith College in North Hampton, Mass., in 1944, Dorothy was a Lt. Jr. Grade in the WAVES in the Naval Communications Intelligence Division. She was stationed at the Naval Communications Annex in Washington, D.C., working on Japanese codes until she was honorably discharged in 1946.

Dorothy married William Franklin “Frank” Wilson on March 23, 1946. They moved to Elmhurst in 1949. Dorothy was an active member of Yorkfield Presbyterian Church, participating in choir, serving on session, teaching 6th grade Sunday School and delivering Meals on Wheels out of Erie Neighborhood House in Chicago every month for 16 years. She was a longtime member of Elizabeth Circle. After taking a Laubach Literacy (Each-One, Teach-One volunteer tutoring program) workshop in 1969, she went on to tutor innumerable students, became a tutor trainer, and started literacy centers in Bensenville, two at Yorkfield Presbyterian Church, Christ Church of Oak Brook, Itasca Presbyterian Church and Elmhurst Memorial Hospital.

Mrs. Wilson was a member of PEO, Church Women United and was a Girl Scout Leader. She was a longtime member of the Morton Arboretum and the Brookfield Zoo. She loved to read and do crossword puzzles. Later in life she started baking cookies every week for the Sunday School children at Yorkfield Presbyterian Church and for the children (and adults) in her neighborhood. She was affectionately known as “The Cookie Lady.”

She is survived by her children, Carol Wilson (Charles Mullen), Nancy Wilson and James (Elizabeth) Wilson; grandchildren, Molly Mullen (Tim Underwood), Amanda (Damon) Beadles, Patrick Mullen and Erin (Graham) Shaw; great granddaughters, Savannah Beadles and Nora Underwood; nieces Charlotte Wilson Stevenson, Sally Wilson Bowie, Margie Wilson Cascarano and nephew Bill Wilson. She was preceded in death by her husband, W. Frank Wilson, her sister, Lillian Williams Strait and her parents, Homer and Betty Williams. Memorial Services were held on Saturday, October 11, 2014 at Yorkfield Presbyterian Church, 1099 S. York Rd., Elmhurst. Interment Private Oakridge Cemetery.

In lieu of flowers, memorials will be appreciated for Heifer International, 1 World Avenue, Little Rock, AR 72202; or Alzheimer’s Association, 8430 W Bryn Mawr Ave., Chicago, IL 60631. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Served 18 years on Elmhurst Park Board; requests tree in lieu of flowers

By Dee Longfellow

For The Elmhurst Independent

Eugene Pomerance of Lombard, formerly of Elmhurst, who enjoyed two parallel careers in business and in public service, died at age 92 of complications from heart disease in Lombard on September 10, 2014.

In a note left for his survivors, Gene, a leading marketing research professional for more than 35 years, suggested, "In lieu of flowers, plant a tree.”

“That suggestion reflects his tireless devotion to both people and open space,” said his daughter Lynne Attaway. “He loved his work in marketing and advertising. He was really good at it and he excelled in mentoring the young people in his department. But he wanted to make a long-lasting difference for the community at large, so, throughout his business career and well into retirement, he lent his expertise to an array of public parks, trails, and conservation groups.”

An MBA graduate of the University of Chicago, his research work in advertising represents a veritable summary of 20th century consumer marketing in America. Among the brands he guided to the marketplace were Ray-O-Vac, Pillsbury, Kool-Aid, Kleenex, Kraft, Pepsodent, Hallmark, Lincoln automobiles (including the Edsel), Goodrich, Hiram Walker, Johnson Wax, Raid, Dial, International Harvester and First National Bank of Chicago. He retired from his professional career as Worldwide Director of Marketing Services for Foote, Cone & Belding (FCB).

Except for his military service, Pomerance spent all of his life in the Chicago area. He was born in 1921 to I. S. Pomerance, a dentist, and Grace F. Smith, a physician, on Chicago’s south side. After attending Chicago public schools, through junior college, he attended the University of Chicago, where he met his future wife, Ginny Lus. His education was interrupted by World War II, during which he served as a sergeant in an armored division and later as a lieutenant in a signal company of the Army Air Corps. Following the war, he earned his MBA in statistics.

Elected three times to six-year terms on the Elmhurst Park District board, Pomerance served as its president for several years. He also served as president of the Illinois Association of Park Districts, was a trustee of the Illinois Park and Recreation Foundation, and for more than a decade was a trustee of the National Recreation and Park Association. He was a founding member of the People for Elmhurst Parks Foundation, served on the board and published the newsletter of the Illinois Prairie Path in its early days, and was a member of the Advisory Board of the Forest Foundation (now The Conservation Foundation).

Following retirement from Foote, Cone & Belding, he returned to school to study landscape design at College of DuPage, with supplementary courses at the Morton Arboretum, leading to work in the landscape architecture department of the Forest Preserve District of DuPage County and the landscape department of the Chicago Park District.

In both of his careers, Pomerance contributed articles to magazines and journals and was a sought-after speaker. He held officer positions in his major professional groups — Marketing, Statistics, and Public Opinion Research — and frequently delivered research papers at local and national meetings of such groups. He also spoke at meetings of the Advertising Research Foundation and the European Society of Opinion and Marketing Research. Equally active in the parks field, he contributed articles and spoke often at meetings of State of Illinois groups and at regional and national conferences.

Between business and retirement, Pomerance and his wife traveled to more than 100 countries on seven continents. He delighted in showing his pictures to travel clubs, civic groups, and to friends at home where his wife would prepare meals indigenous to the countries being described. Some of their trips also involved service, including copying from old church records in Hungary, an archeological dig in Argentina, and teaching English in Poland. At the age of 90, he made his most recent international trips, one to the fjords of Norway and another to Amsterdam to hear a new opera. Widely recognized by his peers, Pomerance was elected to Beta Gamma Sigma, the national honor business fraternity, at the U. of C. He twice received Merit Awards from the American Marketing Association for research papers, was published in the Journal of Marketing, and was listed in Who's Who in Finance & Industry and in Who's Who in America. He served as a part-time instructor in marketing research, statistics, and advertising at the University of Chicago and Northwestern University. In 1989 he was named Commissioner of the Year by the Illinois Association of Park Districts, and was honored with the National Voluntary Service Award by the National Recreation and Park Association in 1994.

Pomerance volunteered for the PTA, Boy Scouts, the Elmhurst YMCA and at Elmhurst Memorial Hospital and, until shortly before his death, was an instructor in the AARP Driver Safety Program for seniors. He also enjoyed classical music as a longtime subscriber to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and the Lyric Opera. His work on a family genealogy provided much satisfaction to him and the opportunity to connect with distant relatives all over the world.

His wife Ginny, whom he married in 1944, preceded him in death after almost 67 years of marriage. In addition to daughter Lynne Attaway, other survivors include his sister Helen Johnson of Chicago; two other children, Diane Koenker of Urbana and Roger Pomerance of Chicago; five grandchildren and five great grandchildren.

James W. “Jim” Panter, Jr., a resident of Villa Park, died Monday morning, September 8, 2014, in Elmhurst Memorial Hospital.

Jim was born August 7, 1935 in Struthers, Ohio, a son of James Walter Panter, Sr. and Edna Allen, who was a descendent of Revolutionary War hero Ethan Allen. Raised in Struthers, he had lived in Cleveland, moving to the Chicago area then to Villa Park in 1967.

He was a 1953 graduate of Struthers High School. He worked at General Extrusions in Youngstown and in construction with the Arnold Company in Cleveland. He then worked in the printing industry where he found his career.

In 1960, his brother Charles founded Associated Data Forms in Oak Park, where Jim worked as well. In 1972, Charles founded Midwest Graphic Industries (MGI) where Jim operated the manufacturing division that printed multi-part business forms. His brother designed and sold to many major companies including DuPage County. In 1983 Jim purchased Midwest Graphic Industries (MGI) from his brother serving as president until his passing. His sons Scott and Jeff have worked with him in the operation of the company which they recently moved to Bensenville.

He was a Life Member of the National Rifle Association, attending the annual conventions with his lifelong friend, Dan Becker, with whom he shared a love of guns and shooting. And, even though he was an almost fanatic Cadillac owner and supporter the two of them enjoyed a Mercedes tour of Germany. He was a member of the Maywood Sportsman’s Club where he was an avid target and trap shooter with his son David.

He leaves his wife the former Nancy Stock, the love of his life, whom he married on October 19, 1955; three sons; Scott (Susan) of Villa Park; David (Margie) of Glendale Heights; and Jeff of Villa Park; a sister Wanda Lou Young of Struthers, Ohio; grandchildren, Johnathon, Michelle, Amanda (Joseph Proud), Abigayle (Jason) Adkins and Austin and a great granddaughter, Aubree. In addition to his parents his brother Charles W. Panter, a sister Mildred Yost and a brother in law, Tom Young are deceased.

Funeral services were held Saturday, September 13, at Steuerle Funeral Home 350 South Ardmore Avenue, Villa Park.

Arrangements provided by Steuerle Funeral Home. Call (630) 832-4161 or visit steuerlefh.com for more information.

Jerome L. Slovick, D.D.S., a longtime resident of Elmhurst, was called home to God on Wednesday, August 20, 2014, just two days after celebrating his 86th birthday. Loving and devoted husband of Ann nee Humenik; father of Jerome L. Jr. (Cathy) Slovick, Dr. Jeffrey (Kathy) Slovick, Dr. Margaret (Donald) Sujack, Sandra (Mark) Theobald and Dr. Robert (Sue) Slovick; grandfather of 12; great grandfather of three; beloved son of the late Alex and Helen Slovick; brother of Ron (Marcia) Slovick.

Jerome was born in Chicago, where he met Ann while playing baseball in their Chicago Logan Square neighborhood. He graduated from Loyola Dental School in Chicago and he and Ann married in 1952. Jerome served his country as a dentist in the Navy during the Korean conflict, stationed in Barstow, California.

Dr. Slovick moved his family to Elmhurst in 1955 and earned the reputation of a caring and meticulous dentist who endeared himself to his patients. His little white dental office near the railroad tracks on Haven Road changed and modernized over the years. But some things stayed the same, such as the sturdy metal treasure chest, loaded with trinkets, the reward that many children (and more than a few adults) looked forward to at the end of the appointment. He went on to practice in Elmhurst for 38 years.

The family acquired a lake house in Twin Lakes, Wisconsin, and enjoyed traveling there together on weekends. In the late 80's, Jerome and Ann bought a second home in Florida and, for the next three decades, they traveled back and forth to Venice, Florida, before moving back to Elmhurst.

Jerome's career was a strong influence on his family. Three of his children and a granddaughter decided to become dentists. Jerome was a member of the Elmhurst T.H.B. Post 187 A.L. and the past president of the Elmhurst Noon Lions Club. He enjoyed golf, sports, bridge, spirited conversation, wood carving, exercise, dancing, spending time with his growing family and traveling with Ann.

Funeral services were held on Monday, August 25, 2014, at Immaculate Conception Church. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, Memorials will be appreciated. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

ADDISON- Dorothy L Ross, 93, a resident of The Vines Senior Home, Elgin, IL (formerly of Addison, IL.) passed away Thursday, July 31, 2014 surrounded by family.

Dorothy was born August 28, 1920 in Batavia, IL. to parents Irvin Sorenson and Emma (David) Sorenson. She had one brother, Irvin (Bud) Sorenson, and two sisters, Millie Hildenberg and Delores Biggerstaff. They resided in Maywood and Bellwood growing up. She graduated Proviso High School in Maywood in 1937. She then attended the University of Illinois at Navy Pier in Chicago from 1953 to 1955.

Dorothy married William Seaman in 1943. Together they raised his 11 year-old son, Raymond J. Seaman. William passed away in 1956.

She worked a variety of jobs throughout her life. William and Dorothy owned three restaurants in the 1940’s. Bill’s Diner, Dewey’s Hamburger, both in Forest Park, and The Lobby Restaurant in Chicago. She was an executive secretary for W.W. Grainger, Inc. from 1950 to 1961. She was an Executive Receptionist from 1961 to 1965. From there she worked until retirement in 1988 at GTE Automatic Electric.

Dorothy has always had religion in her life. She attended St Peters Church in Antioch from 1946-1972. She also was an active member of the Addison Bible Church until it resolved. She then found 1st Baptist Church of Wood Dale, which she was a member of until her death. She was an active prayer warrior in her church.

Dorothy enjoyed traveling. Her favorite place she visited was Washington State. She also enjoyed sewing, cooking, baking and canning.

She met the love of her life, Robert Ross and they married on May 26, 1973. Together they enjoyed camping trips, gardening, and scouting. Dorothy was proud to be recognized as the first female leader in the Co-Ed Explorer post in 1972. She had six step children.

Dorothy was known as a loving, caring, prayerful, thoughtful woman, who was often invited to lead prayer at The Vines. She loved to laugh and touched the hearts of those who knew her.

She is survived by her 2 Granddaughters, Sharon Seaman and Cathy (Darrell) Vaden, and her 3 great grandchildren, Kelly (Jose) Robles, Adam Sorenson, and Shane Seaman. She is also survived by Bob’s children Barbara Resendez, James (Nancy) Ross, Debra (Marty) Coe, Mary Anne (Jeff) Nora, David (Melanie) Ross, and Suzan (John) Eckberg. Dorothy was also blessed by 13 Grandchildren, Scott Resendez, Lisa Resendez, Courtney Ostrowski, Sara Dinardo, Sarah Lawyer, Nancy Sue Ross, Robert Ross, Michael Ross, Shane Nora, Nicole Nora, Alyssa Eckberg, Shelby Eckberg, Allison Eckberg and ten Great Grandchildren.

Dorothy was preceded in death by her husband, Robert Ross, her son Raymond Seaman, both of her parents, and all of her siblings.

Visitation was held on Sunday, August 3, 2014 at Brust Funeral Home, 135 S. Main St., Lombard. Funeral Services were held on Monday, August 4 at Corman Memorial Home in Roseville, IL, with burial following at 2 p.m. at Roseville Cemetery.

Charles George Wolff was born on October 17, 1919, to Adlai Stevenson Wolff and Margaret Bogner Wolff in Chicago. He died on Friday, July 18, 2014, in Littleton, Colo. Charles was a long-time resident of Elmhurst. Charlie is survived by his wife of 64 years, Lorraine Rudy Wolff, his son, Charles Spencer Wolff (Kathleen Giesting), his daughter, Gail Heitland (Ron), and his grandchildren, Kevin and Julie Heitland. He was preceded in death by his son, Bryan, his sister, Margaret, and his brother, Edward.

Charles was a WWII veteran having served in the U.S. Army Artillery as a tank driver and gunner in France, achieving the rank of Corporal. He was awarded a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star for his efforts and bore the marks of his injuries his entire life. He was an active member of the Elmhurst T.H.B. Post #187 A.L.

He married Lorraine Bernadette Rudy on April 29, 1950, after a long pursuit. Together with their friends, they formed the Solaroid Social Club that put on events for each other. He enjoyed golf, cards, and dancing – and was known as “Honest Charlie Wolff” – always quick with a joke or to help a neighbor. Charles worked as a relay engineer for various engineering firms and, in his retirement, for the Bank of Elmhurst. In 1998, he and Lorraine moved from Chicago to enjoy the sun in Las Vegas. In 2009, they moved again – this time to Colorado to be near their daughter and her family.

Funeral Services were held on Saturday, July 26, 2014, at Ahlgrim Funeral Home, 567 S. Spring Rd., Elmhurst. Entombment Irving Park Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, Memorials will be appreciated for the American Legion Elmhurst, 310 W Butterfield Rd, Elmhurst, 630-833-7800 or americanlegionthb187.org; or to the Disabled American Veterans, P.O. Box 14301, Cincinnati OH 45250 or at dav.org via the Donate Now button. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Marylou Lindhorn (nee Weber), age 65, of Homer Glen, passed away on July 10, 2014. Marylou was born on November 14, 1948, in Oak Park, the daughter of Robert and Dorothy Weber. She grew up in Villa Park. Marylou graduated from Willowbrook High School in 1966. In high school she played the violin in the orchestra, took dance lessons, and performed in school musical productions. It was in a production of "The Pajama Game" that she met her future husband.

On August 23, 1969, Marylou married her high school sweetheart, Clifford Lindhorn. They moved to Homer Glen, IL in December, 1978, where Marylou became very involved with the Lioness Club and she was instrumental in the charter of the Homer Township Public Library. In the 2000's, Marylou and her family were very actively involved with charity events such as the Breast Cancer 3-Day, the Avon Walk for Breast Cancer and the Out of the Darkness Walk for Suicide Prevention. Marylou worked for many companies over the years and had just retired in February 2014 from her position with ABS Americas. Marylou was very creative, for many years running her own full-time crafting business. In recent years she became an avid knitter, knitting many sets of hats and gloves that she would take to PADS to give to the homeless in the cold months. Marylou very much enjoyed traveling with her husband, especially on cruises to Hawaii, Mexico and the Caribbean. In the warm months you could find her relaxing with her family at home on their deck. Marylou is survived by her husband of 45 years, Clifford Lindhorn; their daughters Lara (Dennis) Ward and Sara Lindhorn; granddaughters Dekoda Jensen, Kyra Ward and Madisyn Jensen; brother Robert (Shari) Weber, mother Dorothy Weber (nee Newman); father- and mother-in-law Robert and Mary Ellen Lindhorn; brother-in-law Phillip (Carol) Lindhorn; and many beloved nieces, nephews, great-nieces, great-nephews, and cousins.

A service to celebrate her life will be held on Saturday, August 2, 2014 at 11:00 a.m. at Community Congregational Church in Villa Park (410 S. Cornell Ave.).

In lieu of flowers please consider a donation in her honor to the Joliet Area Community Hospice joliethospice.org or the American Cancer Society cancer.org. Arrangements provided by Steuerle Funeral Home. Call (630) 832-4161 or visit steuerlefh.com for more information.

A branch falls from Villa Park’s family tree…

Long-time community volunteer Irene Shaffer passes away at 69

By Dee Longfellow

For The Villa Park Independent

While she had suffered some health problems recently, Irene Shaffer was never one to complain. That is why the community gave a collective gasp at the news that she had passed away at the age of 69.

Irene Shaffer, nee Korynecky, of Villa Park, passed away on June 16, 2014, at Elmhurst Memorial Hospital. Beloved daughter of Alex and the late Maria Korynecky; loving sister of Villa Park Village Clerk Hosanna Korynecky, Gladys (David) Novotny and the late Nester Korynecky. Funeral services were held at Steuerle Funeral Home in Villa Park on June 19, 2014. Interment took place at Mt. Emblem Cemetery.

“Irene was a dedicated volunteer who worked so hard to make a difference in our community and she certainly did,” said Alesia Bailey, executive director of the Villa Park Chamber of Commerce. “We have truly lost a wonderful person.”

Some knew her as a long-time employee at Villa Park National Bank, now BMO Harris Bank. Others people knew Irene through her hundreds of hours of volunteering for the Kiwanis Club, the Community Pride Commission, the Villa Park Historical Commission and many other organizations.

“Until I went to her funeral, I had no idea she was an alto singer,” Bailey said. “She conducted the choir and was a very spiritual person.”

Making her singing debut in public at age 10, Irene not only sang alto and led the choir, but also was involved for years with kids’ music programs.

Irene came to this country from Ukraine with her two sisters and a brother. She took care of her mother for many years until she passed away, then continued to take care of her father who is still alive.

Serving on the Community Pride Commission for many years, she eventually served as chair of the Commission for five years, learning her job under the tutelage of sister Hosanna – the two never went anywhere without each other.

She was always out and about at community activities. As a Kiwanian, Shaffer worked on their fundraisers, including selling tickets to the annual Kiwanis spaghetti dinner served just before a performance of the Willowbrook spring play. You saw Irene at parades, on holidays and other events throughout Villa Park. And she was always willing to help.

“Irene remained relentless in her pursuit to immerse herself in her community to contribute and make a difference,” Bailey said. “I don’t have all the facts [about her volunteer service], but what I do know is that Irene was everywhere. She volunteered even when no one asked. She would just show up and say ‘I’m here to help, what can I do?’

“I think that's what I remember most about her. You never had to ask, you just knew she'd be there, ready to help.”

William Martin “Bill” Fox, died at his home in Rock Island on June 14, 2014, at the age of 88. Family and friends are invited to share memories and celebrate the life and accomplishments of this remarkable husband, brother, uncle, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend on Saturday, June 28, from 1-5 pm at an open house in his grandson’s home, 1336 31st St., Rock Island. Memorials in honor of Bill Fox may be made to: Heritage Fifty-Three, 4601 53rd Street, Moline, IL 61265 (a residential center of The ARC of the Quad City Area).

Bill was born Aug. 4, 1925, in Tulsa, Okla., to William H. Fox and Hazel Irene Cardall Fox. He moved to Andalusia, when he was 5 years old. Bill served in the Navy from 1942 to 1946; this took him from the shores of Normandy on the eve of the invasion to the Marshall Islands on the eve of dropping the atomic bomb.

He married Dolores I. Shrader on Aug. 13, 1950. A bricklayer for more than 30 years, he opened Fox Construction in 1960 where he worked until he retired in 1990.
