A love of cooking led Bill to open Cleo’s Restaurant in Milan in 1964, which he sold to Hardee’s in 1977. He enjoyed cooking original recipes and family feasts his entire life.

A lifetime member of Illinois Local 6 Bricklayers Union, Bill was active for 61 years. He was a member of the Masonic Lodge, Knights of Pythias, and a founding member of the ARC of the Quad City Area.

Bill is survived by his wife, Dolores I. Fox of Rock Island; sister, Martha Fox Polsfuss, of Pillager, Minn.; daughters, Judi Lee Fox of Moline, and Jeri Lynn Fox (husband Michael Kuhlman) of Elmhurst; son, William C. Fox of Elmhurst; grandchildren, William S. (Kylee) Fox, of Rock Island; Christine and Nicole Kuhlman, and Emily Fox, of Elmhurst; and a great-grandson, William Jude Fox of Rock Island.

He was preceded in death by his sister, Gladys Ruby (Sally) Skinner and brother, John H. Fox. Online condolences may be left for the family at wheelanpressly.com. Information provided by family members.

Retired Elmhurst police chief passes away at 103

William Payne served Elmhurst from 1968-78

By Dee Longfellow

For The Elmhurst Independent

William T. Payne, a resident of Lexington Square of Elmhurst, passed away on June 18, 2014, at the Lexington Square Community in Elmhurst at the age of 103. Born and raised in the Montclare area of Chicago near Grand and Harlem Avenues, he attended St. Ignatius High School, graduating with the class of 1929. He was a captain on the Chicago Police Department until his retirement in 1968, when he became the Police Chief of Elmhurst, serving until 1978.

He was the beloved husband of the late Ardele, nee Beberger, for more than 74 years. She died in 2013 at the age of 95. Payne was also the loving father of Tom (Jean) and the late William J (Joan Ward); proud grandfather of Tom and Dave (Tina) and great-grandfather of Jack and Ford; dear brother of the late Vernyle (Dan) Stone and Marion (Phillip) Campbell; fond uncle of Lynn (Lennart) Barkinge, Craig (Jo) Campbell, William (Bonnie) Stone and Terry Stone; cherished son of the late Jule, nee Botheroyd, and the late Joseph.

As a child growing up during the Great Depression, his early days (and many nights) were full of second and third jobs, surrounded by club basketball, football and acting in local plays. In later years his pursuits turned to golf, bowling and his grandchildren.

Reaching adulthood during the lean years of the Great Depression, Payne applied for any job he could. When he celebrated his 100th birthday, he said he never planned on a career in law enforcement, he just landed there.

"I'd had as much an idea of going into police work as the man in the moon,” Payne said, who landed his first law enforcement job in 1936. “But I took any job I could get.”

He served as a traffic officer for the Chicago Park District, which led to his eventual career in law enforcement, culminating with his service as Chief of Police in Elmhurst.

Payne is credited with making several improvements to the Elmhurst department during his tenure. He was responsible in 1974 for the City joining DuComm, a consolidated dispatch center that made better use of the city's resources. He also expanded the forensics and evidence technician programs. While those fields are big today, they were a new and relatively unknown back when Chief Payne served. He brought them into the limelight.

He witnessed such improvements to Elmhurst as the construction of the underpass at Robert Palmer Drive, which was built in the 1970s and provided a way for motorists – and squad cars – to avoid being stopped by the trains that travel along First Avenue.

According to family members, to supplement his salary, Payne had a career as a model on the side and was once known as the “Mr. Hines Lumber man.” His son said he took on the second job so that his sons could attend Catholic schools.

Funeral Mass was held on Tuesday, June 24, 2014, at Visitation Catholic Church. Interment Private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made in Bill's name to Elmhurst Police Benevolent Association (EPBAA), 125 East First Street, Elmhurst.

Visitation and Funeral Mass were held on Tuesday, June 24 at Gibbons Funeral Home, 134 S. York St., Elmhurst. A funeral mass was held at Visitation Catholic Church.

James A. Chevrier, of Hayward, Wisc., formerly of Villa Park, passed away on May 28, 2014, at the Hayward Area Memorial Hospital at the age of 76. He was born in Elmhurst on March 17, 1938, the son of A. Bryan and Margaret (Finnegan) Chevrier. He was raised in Villa Park and was active with scouting, earning the rank of Eagle Scout.

At an early age, Jim developed a love for Corvettes. He purchased his first at the age of 19 and it was a 1957 Corvette with which he won the World Series of Drag Racing in Cordova, Ill. Jim joined U.S. Army in 1961 and served two years in El Paso, where he worked in the motor pool. He was honorably discharged from active duty in 1963 but served in the reserves until 1967.

On May 28, 1966, Jim was joined in marriage to Helen Valerie Schmitz at St. Alexander Catholic Church in Villa Park. He worked for Northern Illinois Gas Company before and after his time in the service. He started work there as a car washer and gasser and then moved up to transportation (coordinator) Technician as a fleet mechanic, and then pipeline inspector. He worked for the company for 40 years and retired in 1996. He served as Union Steward for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers in Illinois.

In 1997 Jim and Helen moved to Hayward, Wisc., on Grindstone Lake where Jim and his family have owned property since the 1950s. Jim enjoyed skiing, gardening and taking meticulous care of his yard. He was a member of the Eagle Scout Association and the Elmhurst Ski Club for many years. He is still a proud owner of a 2010 Corvette.

Jim is survived by his wife of 48 years, Helen; and one brother-in-law, John Schmitz JR (Rosemary); one nephew, John Schmitz III and a great nephew, John Schmitz IV. He was preceded in death by his parents.

In lieu of flowers memorials may be directed to Disabled American Veterans, PO Box 14301, Cincinnati, OH 45250-0301; or Northwoods Humane Society, Hayward, Wisc.

Memorial Visitation will be Saturday June 7, 2014, from 1 to 3 p.m. at Steuerle Funeral Home 350 S. Ardmore Ave, Villa Park. Arrangements provided by Steuerle Funeral Home. Call (630) 832-4161 or visit steuerlefh.com for more information.

Larthenia “Tina” Coomes Squire, of Toulon, Ill., formerly of Elmhurst, passed away at 1:00 a.m. on Wednesday, April 23, 2014, at the Toulon Rehabilitation and Health Care Center in Toulon. She was 96 years old. She was born on November 23, 1917, in Hagerstown, Indiana, to Granville L. and Rosa Nell (Thalls) Coomes. She married Robert E. Wagner in February of 1941. They were divorced in 1963. She married Marshall M. Squire on July 2, 1963. Surviving are two sons: David (Patricia) Wagner, of Hereford, AZ, and Robert Squire of Elmhurst; two daughters: Katherine Squire of Chicago, and Janet (Robert) Wilkinson of Wyoming, Ill.; 11 grandchildren; and 15 great-grandchildren. She is also survived by her sister Edna (John) Boiles of Lake St. Louis, MO. She was preceded in death by her husband in June of 1996, and a son, John Wagner, in November of 2012. Also preceding her in death were her parents and two brothers, Robert Coomes and Granville J. Coomes. Tina graduated from Hagerstown-Jefferson Township High School in 1935. She worked at The Keebler Company in Elmhurst, in the payroll department for 14 years, retiring in 1985. She enjoyed reading, crossword puzzles, crocheting and counted cross-stitch. She was also an avid fan of Chicago Cubs baseball and loved listening to the games on the radio. Tina was a member of the First Congregational Church in Toulon, where she was active in the Super Seniors Sunday School class. She was also a member of the Toulon American Legion Auxiliary, the Toulon Women’s Club, and the U.S.S. Hancock Association. Funeral services were held on Saturday, April 26. Burial will be in West Lawn Cemetery in Hagerstown, Ind., on May 3, 2014. Memorials may be made to the Toulon Public Library District or MSW Projects (Toulon Nutrition Site). Arrangements are being handled by Haskell-Hott Funeral Homes, Toulon. Condolences may be sent to the family via www.haskellhott.com.

Lucita Somcio Gomez passed away at her home in Elmhurst on February 26, 2014. She had been battling a recurrence of breast cancer for over three years. Lucy was born on November 19, 1943, in Santa Barbara in the Philippine Province of Iloilo. Lucy was the fifth of nine children, with two sisters and six brothers. She attended the University of the Philippines in Manila, and received her Diploma in Nursing in 1965. After graduating, Lucy eventually moved to Toronto, Ontario, Canada, where she met her husband Nicanor Gomez. Nicanor and Lucy were married in Chicago in 1970 and moved to Elmhurst in 1976. While working and living in Elmhurst, Lucy continued her education, receiving a Bachelor of Science in Nursing and Psychology (with honors) from Elmhurst College in 1982 and a Master of Science in Nursing from DePaul University in 1988. Lucy was a caring and dedicated nurse for more than 45 years. She worked as a nurse, nurse manager and in-service education coordinator at a number of local institutions, including Elmhurst Memorial Hospital, Gottlieb Memorial Hospital, Lifelink Anchorage, and Marianjoy Rehabilitation Hospital. Lucy also loved to teach, and served as an adjunct faculty member at College of DuPage, Morton College and Triton College. Lucy enjoyed music, reading, crossword puzzles and spending time with her grandsons. She especially enjoyed exploring the many wonderful museums in Chicago with her grandsons during their visits to Chicago. Lucy is survived by her husband, Nicanor Gomez; her daughter Lisa Gomez, son-in-law Eric Rogers, and grandsons Bobby and Zachary Rogers; her brother Ramon Somcio Jr. and sister-in-law Irene Somcio; her sister-in-law Nelly Somcio; her sister Remedios Somcio; her sister Gloria Palada and brother-in-law Jose Palada; and her brother Angel Somcio and sister-in-law Lilet Somcio. She was preceded in death by her brothers Dominador, Amado, Inocencio, and Antonio Somcio. Visitation will be held on Friday, April 4 from 3-9 p.m. at the Pedersen Ryberg Mortuary, 435 N. York Street in Elmhurst. A funeral prayer service will be held at the mortuary on Saturday, April 5, 2014, at 9 a.m., followed by a procession to Mary Queen of Heaven Church, 426 N. West Ave in Elmhurst. The Funeral Mass will be held at 10 a.m. Interment will be at Queen of Heaven Cemetery in Hillside. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that memorials be given in Lucy’s name to the American Cancer Society (cancer.org) or the Breast Cancer Research Foundation (bcrfcure.org). For more information, contact Pedersen Ryberg Mortuary at (630) 834-1133 or pedersenryberg.com.

Former long-time 4th Ward Alderman dies John Gow passes away after 17-year fight against cancer

By Dee Longfellow

For The Elmhurst Independent

With incredible courage and optimism, former 4th Ward Alderman John Gow battled both prostate cancer and multiple myeloma for 17 years. Last week, the Independent learned that the former 4th Ward Alderman who served on City Council for 12 years lost his valiant fight and passed away. Seventh Ward Alderman Mark Mulliner had this to say about his former colleague on the City Council dais. “John Gow was a thoughtful individual, who was also a gentleman no matter if you agreed with his position or disagree. He was good man with the best interest of the community in mind at all times.” Former Mayor Tom Marcucci echoed Mulliner’s comments. “John Gow loved Elmhurst, which was very apparent in the passion he brought to the job of Alderman for the 4th Ward.” Susan Rose, a ZPC Commissioner and former 3rd Ward Alderman offered this: “He was a gentleman on the dais and well-respected by many of his constituents.” The devoted husband to Olivia, nee Greco, for 52 years, John was the loving and proud father of John and Anne; and, a cherished and doting grandpa of Sara. He was born March 5, 1931 in Attleboro, Mass., graduated from Wilbraham Academy, earned a B.A. from Allegheny College, an M.A. from University of Iowa, and an M.S. from I.I.T. John taught speech communication at Elmhurst College from 1961-1993. After retirement he served as “a voice of reason” on the Elmhurst City Council as an alderman for 12 years. A lifelong Dodger fan, an avid tennis player, a good and gentle man yet a warrior in his fight against cancer. Visitation was held on Wednesday, March 12, 2014, from 3-8 p.m. at Gibbons Funeral Home, 134 South York Road, Elmhurst. Mass was held Thursday, March 13 at 9:30 a.m. at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church. Burial at Saint Mary Catholic Cemetery. Arrangements provided by Gibbons Funeral Home. Call (630) 832-0018 or visit gibbonsfuneralhome.com for more information.

Over the weekend, the Independent learned that Ralph F. Tellefsen, Jr., a native of Elmhurst, had recently passed away recently. He was the loving husband of Charmaine, nee Moore, for more than 63 years; devoted father of Charmaine (Charles) Jones, Ralph "Fritz", III (Nancy) and Christiane (Peter Jensen) Tellefsen M.D.; proud and loving grandfather of Leland Edward Tellefsen, Anna Elizabeth and Daniel Alexander Jensen; cherished son of the late Ralph F., Sr. and the late Grace K., nee Horn.

Ralph was confirmed in the Lutheran Church - Missouri Synod at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Addison on December 25, 1949, and married there the following year. Ralph was a long time Elmhurst businessman owning his real estate and insurance business on York Road for more than 50 years.

The Independent caught up with Alex King of King Construction who began his own real estate career with Tellefsen back in the 1960s.

“Ralph was a very low-key, laid-back kind of guy,” King said. “He stressed knowing your product, getting out and visiting every home [that] went on the market. He believed you should go through every single house on the market that was available. He didn’t believe in the listing books, he believed you should know you product and know your customers and find a match for them. He was very well-respected, having been in the Elmhurst community a long time.

“Ralph was helpful cooperative, he knew just about everybody in town, he was not big on paperwork, he believed you should find the person, learn what they needed and everything else will fall in to place.”

Services were held on Monday, December 30, 2013, at Redeemer Lutheran Church in Elmhurst. Interment Mount Emblem Cemetery. For funeral information, please call 630-832-0018 or gibbonsfuneralhome.com

Services to be held Jan. 4

On December 23, 2013, Alvin “Al /Tip” Charles Skat, Jr. passed away after a courageous year-long struggle with pancreatic cancer. He was the son of the late Ordie and Alvin Skat, Sr. Al is survived by his wife, Sandra Brown Skat of Elmhurst; daughters, Molly Skat (Aaron Hunt) of Thorn, The Netherlands; and Betsy Skat Kruse (Lucas) of Iowa City; granddaughters Adley and Cora Kruse; sister, Esme (Raoul) Ehr, of Elm Grove, Wisc.; a brother, Mike (Leigh) Skat of Sanford, Fla.; and nieces and nephews Dalton, Cooper and Sloan Skat, Brenden and Maggie Brown, and Alissa and Abby Vriezelaar.

Al was born in Milwaukee on October 15, 1950 and lived in Waukesha and DePere, Wisc., before moving to Brown Deer, where he went to high school. He earned bachelors and masters degrees in mechanical engineering from Purdue University and his MBA from the University of Chicago. He lived his adult life in Norridge and Elmhurst, working as a mechanical engineer designing many different products ranging from bar code printers to automobile switches. He was a licensed professional engineer and had several patents to his credit.

Al was respected for his thoughtful consideration of others, along with his sense of fun and humor. There was nothing he loved more than his family, fishing and spending time at the family cabin in northern Wisconsin. He also liked reading, music, camping, hiking, and cars.

A memorial service celebrating his life will be held on Saturday, January 4 at 11 a.m., at Elmhurst Presbyterian Church, 367 Spring Road, Elmhurst.

In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to: Elmhurst Presbyterian Church (address above); New Tribes Mission for Betsy and Luke Kruse, 1000 East First Street Sanford, FL 32771; or the Caring Bridge Donation Processing Center, PO Box 6032, Albert Lea, MN 56007.

Nancy C. Tullsen, nee Clegg, a longtime area resident, passed away from a rare form of cancer at her home in Elmhurst on November 25, 2013, at the age of 71. Beloved wife of J. Peter Tullsen; dear mother of Barbara (Daniel Hill) Tullsen Hill and John P. (Evan Siegel) Tullsen, Jr.; cherished nana of Wesley Tullsen Hill and Alaina Elizabeth Hill; loving daughter of the late Alice Revell Clegg and Dr. Lawrence Clegg; adored sister of Carolyn (Stephen) Hemman and Howard Clegg; aunt of devoted nephews and nieces.

Nancy was born and raised in Norwich, Conn., and graduated from Gettysburg College in 1963 with a double major in history and education. She met her husband of 50 years there. Nancy and her family moved around the country more than a dozen times, primarily due to her husband’s job transfers, but she always quickly made friends, embraced her fresh surroundings, and redecorated her new homes. Her primary career and highest priority was raising her family, but Nancy also pursued a variety of positions, including elementary school teacher, bookkeeper, visitors’ center representative and several bank customer service positions.

Among her many interests and talents, Nancy was renowned for her craft projects, from making candles to creating pinecone wreaths to re-upholstering furniture. She also singlehandedly repainted the interiors of all her new homes and was a superb landscaper. Nancy would keep up with the ins and outs of the financial markets, the latest recipes and TV shows ranging from “Law & Order” to anything on the History Channel. She also was a master entertainer, renowned for her generosity and thoughtfulness. Gracious and ever interested in others, Nancy always put people at ease and enjoyed discussing everything from news, culture, food, and most of all, family. Nancy will be remembered for her sweet, caring, classy, and genteel personality, and will be forever missed by her family and many friends. Memorial Visitation was held on Saturday, November 30, 2013. In lieu of flowers, please donate to a cancer charity of your choice. Services and Interment private. Arrangements provided by Ahlgrim Funeral Home. Call (630) 834-3515 or visit ahlgrim.com for more information.

Marcellus “Jim/Marc” Holland Jr. passed away on November 27, 2013, at Elmhurst Memorial Hospital, at the age of 71. He was born in Oak Park on July 25, 1942. Jim was preceded in death by his parents Polly and Mike Holland; his father-in-law Edward Frank; a brother-in-law Philip Frank; his step-father-in-law Stanley Wojcik; and a half-brother David Lee McKinstray. Jim is survived by his dear wife of 45 years, Judy, nee Frank, Holland. He is also survived by his loving children Marc (Jennifer) Holland and Marguerite (Tom) Reamer; grandchildren Justin and Elisa Reamer and Mike Holland; sister Jane Holland. Additional family members who survive include Jim’s mother-in-law Florence Wojcik; sister-in-law Annette Frank; nephew Sean Holland; niece Christine Frank, as well as numerous relatives and friends.

Jim graduated from Ascension Grade School and Fenwick High School in Oak Park and received a B.S. degree from Lewis University in Romeoville. His entire 50-year business career was spent in banking. At the time of his death, Jim was employed at the Hoffman Estates Community Bank and Hanover Park Community Bank
